CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: What if Clinton's emphasis on international cooperation and collaboration leads to a decrease in the already strained relationships between the US and some Middle Eastern countries, potentially hindering the collection of intelligence and the fight against terrorism?

Does any scientific research or empirical evidence support the claim that cooperating with Muslim nations and the American Muslim community would be more effective in gathering intelligence and combating terrorism, given the complexities and nuances of cultural and religious dynamics in these regions?

Wouldn't the Clinton administration's approach to counter-terrorism, which involves cooperating with Muslim-majority nations and the American Muslim community, be analogous to the idea that second-generation Americans from minority groups should be able to benefit from their ancestors' historical experiences in a similar manner to how whites benefit from their ancestors' experiences, thereby challenging the notion of racial and ethnic privilege?

If strengthening international relationships and cooperation is crucial in the fight against terrorism, why does the president's approach towards Muslim-majority nations, which Clinton describes as dismissive and alienating, undermine these efforts?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: If the wealthy are required to pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes, would that not incentivize companies to shift their resources and focus on increasing executive compensation to maintain the existing profit-sharing disparity?

Don't you think that simply redistributing wealth from the wealthy to the working class might lead to a disincentivization of entrepreneurship and investment, thereby potentially harming the economy in the long run?

If the wealthy are expected to pay their fair share in order to fund social programs, would it not be equitable to expect corporations to share their profits more equally among their workers, rather than just the executives at the top?

If the wealthy are to be taxed to fund these initiatives, doesn't that constitute an unfair burden on those who have already contributed to the economy through their hard work and entrepreneurial spirit?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: What if adopting the policies that failed during the economic crisis, such as those proposed by Donald, leads to a relapse into the abyss Clinton mentioned, potentially undoing the progress made in recovering from it?
Can independent experts be relied upon to provide unbiased analysis if they have a history of being selected and funded by the government, thereby potentially creating a conflict of interest?

Doesn't the economic recovery and potential progress outlined by Clinton imply that the policies she's proposing are a more effective solution than the ones that led to the economic downturn, thus making the argument that we should stick with the status quo and return to previous policies, as suggested by Trump, seem counterintuitive?

If the economy was able to recover from the severe consequences of the previous policies, why do you still claim that reverting to those policies would lead us back to the abyss, rather than being a predictable continuation of the cycle?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: What if the US and its allies' continued involvement in NATO and the perceived threat from Iran are more likely to escalate tensions rather than prevent nuclear proliferation and terrorism?

Is it not a contradiction to invoke Article 5 to justify NATO's involvement in Afghanistan but not to justify US involvement in Iraq, given that both countries were seen as threats to global security at the time?

If the US considers Iran's nuclear program a threat to global security, would not the US also consider a similarly equipped and sanctioned North Korea a threat, and therefore, would it not be logical to take similar action against North Korea?

Why should the US and its NATO allies invoke Article 5 to fight terrorism in Afghanistan, but not apply similar collective defense measures to address the nuclear threats posed by North Korea, given that Iran was similarly sanctioned for its nuclear ambitions under the Bush administration?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: What if the effectiveness of the sanctions and the resulting diplomatic efforts, rather than the fact that they were imposed by the speaker, was the primary factor in driving Iran to the negotiating table?

Does the comparison between the sanctions you imposed as a senator and the deal reached by your successor, John Kerry, and President Obama, demonstrate that your assertion of good judgment is solely based on the outcome, rather than the process and methods employed?

If successfully driving Iran to the negotiating table and preventing nuclear proliferation through diplomatic means is considered a demonstration of effective leadership, does that imply that the absence of military action is inherently synonymous with "not good judgment" in all situations?

If Clinton's approach of imposing sanctions and building a coalition was effective in stopping Iran's nuclear program without firing a shot, why couldn't similar diplomatic efforts be applied to North Korea to achieve a peaceful resolution?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: What if being taunted by the media and the public affects a president's mental health and well-being, causing them to make impulsive decisions that could compromise national security?
Can you provide a scholarly study that supports the claim that a president's temperament, as it relates to being "taunted," is a critical factor in their ability to lead as commander-in-chief?

If being able to withstand taunts and criticism is a necessary temperament for a president, then why would it be unacceptable for a woman to display similar resilience in the face of sexism and misogyny?

Is the candidate's temperament, as demonstrated by their ability to handle criticism and insults, a reliable indicator of their fitness to hold the office of commander-in-chief in the face of the complex and often hostile international relations that come with the presidency?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: What if a cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons among world leaders, such as the one Clinton is criticizing, inadvertently emboldens or inspires terrorist groups to pursue nuclear materials, thereby increasing the likelihood of a catastrophic scenario Clinton is warning against?

Does the threat posed by terrorists obtaining nuclear material outweigh the threat posed by the president's alleged "cavalier attitude" towards nuclear weapons, and if so, what evidence suggests that the latter is the "number-one threat we face in the world"?

If the threat of nuclear weapons is the number-one threat we face in the world, why is the threat of nuclear weapons falling into the hands of terrorists not considered a more pressing concern than the threat of terrorists in general?

Is the characterization of North Korea's nuclear program as the "number-one threat" in the world a justification for prioritizing military action over diplomatic efforts, when other countries with nuclear capabilities, like Pakistan and India, have had nuclear conflicts without triggering a similar level of alarm from the US?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: What if the current system or solution being described by the phrase 'It's a good one' is ultimately ineffective in addressing the problem it claims to solve?
Do you have any concrete data to support the claim that the issue being described is indeed a 'problem' in the context provided?

If the analogy between the historical injustices faced by communities of color and the benefits received by whites who have been in the United States for generations is valid, why would the same principle of reparative justice not apply to other marginalized groups, such as indigenous peoples, who have been displaced and disenfranchised for centuries?
If Clinton finds it a good description of the problem, then does this imply that she agrees with the sentiment expressed in the statement?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: What if Clinton's emphasis on secrecy and vagueness about her plan to defeat ISIS inadvertently undermines her argument that she is a leader people can count on, thereby damaging her credibility and effectiveness in addressing global challenges?

Does the notion that the current administration's approach to dealing with Iran is "very successful" align with the stated intention to "stand up to bullies" and protect American interests and security, considering the potential risks and consequences of this approach?

Why does Clinton's emphasis on having a'secret plan' to defeat ISIS not raise similar concerns about transparency and accountability as the secrecy surrounding Trump's proposed policies, despite Clinton's criticism of Trump's lack of a clear plan?

Why should the success of a deal that has given us access to Iranian facilities be a justification for not critically evaluating its terms, when the consequences of the deal could potentially compromise American interests and security?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: What if the deployment of a half a billion more solar panels and the construction of a new modern electric grid create significant job opportunities in the renewable energy sector, but also displace workers in the fossil fuel industry, potentially exacerbating economic disruption and social unrest?

How can deploying a half a billion more solar panels and building a new modern electric grid, as you propose, reconcile with the significant investments and jobs lost in the fossil fuel industry that would be displaced by such a transition?

Would implementing policies solely focused on economic growth through the deployment of solar panels and grid modernization necessarily address the systemic issues that led to the economic troubles in the first place, or is it a Band-Aid solution that overlooks more fundamental reforms?

If the focus is on both domestic and international action, why not prioritize addressing the root causes of economic stagnation, such as income inequality and corporate tax evasion, alongside the deployment of solar panels and grid infrastructure?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: If enforcing trade deals and increasing American exports, as you did when you were secretary of state, is supposed to create new jobs, then why did the growth in exports under your watch as secretary of state not translate to a corresponding decrease in unemployment or an increase in middle-class jobs?

Can you provide evidence that your administration's record of increasing exports during your tenure as Secretary of State actually led to a net gain in American jobs, rather than just an increase in exports that may have been offset by losses in other sectors?

If Clinton's stance on trade deals as secretary of state, which led to significant increases in American exports, is seen as effective, wouldn't similar economic policies and diplomatic efforts be necessary to address the economic challenges faced by other nations, rather than solely relying on a special prosecutor to hold people accountable?

If enforcing the trade deals and holding people accountable is a key part of your economic plan, doesn't that imply that the lack of enforcement and accountability in the past, such as under NAFTA, was a significant contributor to the economic challenges we face today?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: What if Clinton's past experience as a senator and secretary of state doesn't necessarily translate to the kind of leadership and problem-solving skills required to tackle the complex issues facing the country as president?

Can you provide concrete evidence that being a senator or secretary of state necessarily translates to relevant experience in the specific role of the presidency, as opposed to other political offices?

If being a senator and secretary of state are comparable to the experience and qualifications required for the presidency, would Clinton's lack of military experience be analogous to the lack of similar experience among minority groups in the context of affirmative action?
What specific foreign policy accomplishments can you point to from your time as secretary of state that are comparable to the accomplishments you achieved as a senator?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: What if prioritizing new jobs and investments over tax cuts leads to a significant increase in national debt, potentially jeopardizing the country's economic stability in the long run?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that investments are more effective in stimulating the economy and creating new jobs compared to tax cuts?

Would prioritizing short-term economic growth through tax cuts that increase the national debt be analogous to the long-term costs and consequences experienced by communities of color due to historical injustices and systemic inequalities?
If promoting the economy through investments is a key priority, doesn't the massive debt accumulated from previous tax cuts undermine the potential for economic growth in the long term?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: If the economic policies proposed in "Stronger Together" would indeed result in a recession and job loss, how does that reconcile with the claim that they would create 10 million jobs?

Where in your book "Stronger Together" do you provide specific, data-driven projections for the job creation and economic growth you claim would result from your policies, and how do these projections account for potential variables and uncertainties in the economy?
If Clinton's plan is based on a book she wrote, but Trump's plan is not supported by a book, does that not create a double standard in evaluating the credibility of their respective proposals?

If you claim your plan would create 10 million jobs, how do you respond to critics who argue that your proposal's projected economic growth and job creation are overly optimistic and based on unrealistic assumptions?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: If the wealthy and corporations have made all the gains in the economy, as Clinton claims, then why should they be held solely responsible for paying their fair share of taxes to support the country?

Do you have a study that scientifically measures the claim that the wealthy have made all the gains in the economy, considering the economic benefits to other groups such as the middle class and low-income individuals?

Why do claims that the wealthy and corporations should "pay their fair share" in taxes necessarily imply that they have not been contributing sufficiently to the country's support, while simultaneously arguing that two generations of a group's presence in the US would not automatically entitle them to the same benefits as the dominant group?

If your proposal aims to cut regulations for small businesses while increasing taxes on the wealthy, wouldn't that disproportionately benefit the very corporations that have made all the gains in the economy, rather than the middle or lower classes that you claim to support?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: Doesn't a tax system that rewards work over financial transactions inherently perpetuate the existing economic disparities, where those who were already "fortunate" in life, like Donald Trump, will continue to accumulate wealth and influence, rather than addressing income inequality and creating opportunities for the working class?

Don't you think that your assertion that the current tax system rewards financial transactions over work is a simplification of a complex issue and lacks consideration for the various economic theories that suggest a more nuanced approach to taxation?

Doesn't the fact that Clinton's family has been wealthy and privileged, and she mentions Donald Trump's good fortune as a point of contrast, undermine her argument that her own economic policies would benefit the majority of Americans rather than just the wealthy?

Doesn't the fact that you and Trump share a differing view on how to grow the economy, while he has been "fortunate" in his life, undermine your argument that his tax plan would be detrimental to the country's economy?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: What if the success of one's business is not solely dependent on their individual effort, as Clinton implies with her father's example, but also on systemic factors such as access to capital, education, and government policies that favor the wealthy, and how might that impact one's perception of the role of wealth distribution in economic growth?

Can you provide data or studies that demonstrate a direct correlation between helping the wealthy and overall economic growth, as you claim will occur when more resources are invested in the middle class?

Does the notion that a self-made success story like the speaker's father, who achieved success through hard work and small business, justify ignoring the systemic inequalities and privileges that allowed the speaker himself to start a business with $14 million borrowed from his father?
Isn't the notion that wealth is solely generated through inheritance, rather than through hard work and entrepreneurship, a flawed assumption that undermines the value of meritocracy?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: What if reducing corporate tax rates without addressing the repatriation of foreign earnings would not actually lead to the desired outcome of bringing back the money that's stranded overseas?

Do you have a concrete economic model or study that demonstrates how your tax proposals would indeed lead to the repatriation of money that's currently stranded overseas, and not just a hypothetical assumption?

If corporations can repatriate money that's been "stranded overseas" after a brief period of tax scrutiny, shouldn't individuals who have been "stranded" in the US for generations, due to systemic injustices, be allowed to reap the benefits of their ancestors' contributions to American society?
If the Clinton administration's policies led to the repatriation of foreign-held funds, why did they not implement similar measures during their previous terms in office?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: What if the proposed policy that benefits the business, as described by Clinton, would ultimately lead to negative consequences for the broader society, thereby undermining the claim that it would work to the benefit of the public?
Does the proposed policy that Clinton is referring to have any empirical evidence supporting its effectiveness in benefiting society, beyond its potential advantages for Trump's business interests?

Wouldn't the Clinton's assertion that she supports a policy for the benefit of herself and her business, despite its potential advantages, undermine her argument that she is genuinely advocating for the policy's greater good?

If the Clinton administration is aware of the loophole that benefits Trump, why didn't they address or close it during their time in office, instead of allowing it to persist and potentially benefit him now?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance theirâ€”their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: If slashing taxes on the wealthy has not worked to boost the economy, as you mentioned, then what specific policy measures, other than raising taxes on the wealthy, would you propose to achieve broad-based, inclusive growth in America?

Do you have any empirical evidence that supports the claim that middle-class focused policies like free college education and debt refinancing are more effective in boosting the economy than trickle-down economics, especially considering the economic outcomes of the 2008 and 2009 financial crisis?

If economic policies aimed at boosting the economy by targeting the middle class are effective, why wouldn't a more targeted approach of providing benefits to the most vulnerable members of society also lead to positive economic outcomes?

If trickle-down economics, which has been discredited by its failure to address the economic crisis of 2008, is so ineffective, then how can the current economic system, which has been influenced by trickle-down principles, be expected to achieve broad-based and inclusive growth without significant policy changes?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is foolâ€™s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: If lenders and borrowers are aware of the concept of moral hazard and its consequences, does this not incentivize them to take on more prudent lending and borrowing practices to mitigate the risks associated with it?

Does the existence of moral hazard necessarily imply that ignoring it would lead to a complete loss of real wealth, or could alternative risk management strategies mitigate its effects without rendering the wealth generated as "fool's gold"?
If lenders are expected to bear the moral hazard of lending and borrowing, why shouldn't borrowers also be held accountable for the moral hazard of ignoring their own financial responsibilities?
If suppressing moral hazard leads to "fool's gold," isn't the real wealth generated by ignoring it in the first place still wealth that can be used to support economic growth and development?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: If the airline industry is already providing alternative food options and implementing measures to minimize peanut residue, would a complete ban on peanut products be a disproportionate response that could inadvertently cause economic hardship for airlines and their employees without significantly reducing the risk of peanut-related reactions?

Don't you think that a blanket ban on peanuts on all airlines might inadvertently lead to the creation of a false sense of security, causing passengers with peanut allergies to become complacent and less vigilant about their own safety, potentially resulting in more severe reactions in the long run?

If banning peanuts on airlines can prevent life-threatening reactions, wouldn't a similar ban on products containing nuts or other common allergens in schools also be a necessary choice to protect children's lives?

If peanuts are such a significant threat, why haven't airlines and the food industry been able to find more effective and practical solutions, such as substituting peanuts with alternative snacks, rather than resorting to a complete ban?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: What if the intense hostility displayed during the GOP debates actually ends up turning off potential voters who would have otherwise supported the Republican nominee, ultimately benefiting the Democratic candidate in the general election?

Do you have any evidence that the tone and tenor of the GOP debates are representative of the entire party or its base, or are you generalizing based on a specific subset of candidates and their performances?

Does the comparison of the GOP debates to a domestic family conflict imply that the democratic nominee's performance is being unfairly judged based on the tone and behavior of their opponents rather than their own qualifications and policies?

Doesn't the overly aggressive tone of the GOP debate actually serve to reinforce negative perceptions of the Republican Party among undecided voters, potentially harming the party's chances in the general election?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: If the risk of airborne peanut particles causing a severe allergic reaction could potentially be mitigated with stricter airline regulations and safety protocols, should the travel industry prioritize the safety of passengers with severe food allergies over the convenience of air travel for the general public?

Don't you think that the emphasis on the unpredictability of peanut allergies and the severity of reactions might be used to justify restricting the lives of individuals with peanut allergies rather than pushing for more comprehensive safety measures in public spaces, such as nut-free zones in airplanes?

If having a life-threatening peanut allergy that requires constant vigilance and poses significant risks to one's health and career prospects is considered a disability, would this not also qualify individuals with severe mental health conditions that significantly impact their daily functioning and long-term goals as deserving of accommodations and support?

If severe food allergies can be a legitimate reason to restrict one's travel, then why should individuals with severe food allergies be forced to choose between their health and their career choices, especially when accommodations like peanut-free flights and workplaces are not readily available?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: What if accommodating the needs of peanut allergy sufferers through voluntary arrangements with airlines or individual precautions, as suggested by the Frequent Flyer, is more effective in ensuring their safety than a blanket regulation banning peanuts from flights?

Don't you think that the analogy between peanut allergies and medical conditions requiring rescue medication oversimplifies the severity and unpredictability of peanut allergies, potentially leading to inadequate protection for those with life-threatening allergies?

If airline passengers are expected to make accommodations for the health and safety of allergy sufferers, should they also be required to make similar accommodations for passengers with other medical conditions, such as those who require oxygen tanks or have epilepsy, and if so, to what extent?

Doesn't the requirement for airlines to accommodate peanut allergy sufferers imply that flying is inherently unsafe, and therefore, shouldn't airlines be required to take more comprehensive measures to mitigate this risk, rather than just asking passengers to forgo eating peanuts?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: If an assault weapons ban has already been deemed ineffective by the DOJ in addressing homicide rates in the US, then what alternative solutions or strategies should be pursued to effectively reduce gun-related violence and homicide rates?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that an assault weapons ban would have no impact on addressing homicide rates in the US, as stated by the DOJ, or is this a personal opinion?

If the effectiveness of a policy solution is determined to be ineffective after thorough analysis, why should a similar ineffective policy, in this case an assault weapons ban, be proposed as a solution to the same problem?

If the DOJ has already determined that an assault weapons ban won't effectively address homicide rates in the US, then what specific evidence or alternative strategies would support the proposal to implement such a ban?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: What if the racial profiling inherent in stop-and-frisk policies leads to increased mistrust and hostility towards law enforcement among the targeted communities, ultimately causing them to be less cooperative and more resistant to reporting crimes?

Don't you think the court's decision could be seen as perpetuating the stereotype that black and Hispanic men are more likely to be criminals, rather than addressing the systemic issues with the stop-and-frisk policy itself?

If the practice of stop-and-frisk, which disproportionately targeted black and Hispanic individuals, is deemed unconstitutional due to its discriminatory nature, why would similar policies targeting other minority groups not be subject to the same scrutiny and potentially be considered unconstitutional as well?

If the stop-and-frisk policy was deemed unconstitutional due to its disproportionate targeting of black and Hispanic young men, doesn't this undermine the argument that such policies are necessary for public safety, and could it be that the supposed benefits of such policies are actually a pretext for racial profiling?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: What if adopting a policy of first use of nuclear weapons would lead to a retaliatory response from other nations, thereby increasing the likelihood of global nuclear conflict and catastrophic consequences?

Does the current policy on first use of nuclear weapons align with the changing global security landscape and emerging threats, or should it be reevaluated to prioritize the evolving nature of international relations and potential risks to global stability?

If the US government considers altering its policy on nuclear weapons, a decision that could have far-reaching global implications, shouldn't it also re-examine its stance on other long-standing policies, such as those related to racial and ethnic disparities, which could have significant impacts on the lives of its citizens?
Is a policy of maintaining the option for first use of nuclear weapons not a contradictory stance to the moral imperative to prioritize diplomacy and restraint in conflict resolution?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money toâ€”who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: What if the potential president's undisclosed tax returns reveal significant conflicts of interest that could impact their decision-making process, potentially leading to policies that benefit their own financial interests over those of the American people?

Can you provide evidence that the public's right to know about a potential president's tax returns and business conflicts is a precedent that has been consistently upheld in American history, or is this a unique case that sets a new standard for transparency?

If the public scrutiny of a presidential nominee's financial records is necessary to prevent potential conflicts of interest, shouldn't the same level of transparency be applied to the tax returns of all high-level government officials, including those in the current administration?

If releasing tax returns is crucial for transparency and avoiding conflicts of interest, why should exceptions be made for a presidential candidate like HOLT who claims to prioritize transparency, yet has not provided his tax returns?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "theyâ€™re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes Iâ€™d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
itâ€™s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: What if intervening in families with high levels of aggression and violence actually ends up causing unintended consequences, such as further traumatizing the children or driving the parents further into isolation, thereby making the situation worse?

Don't you think that prioritizing intervention for families with high levels of aggression and violence over those who are struggling to provide a stable environment may inadvertently penalize the latter, potentially exacerbating the cycle of disadvantage and poverty?

If intervening in the lives of families with high levels of aggression and violence is justified, shouldn't similar interventions be considered for families struggling with systemic barriers to accessing resources, such as poverty or lack of access to education?

If we're intervening in cases where families are causing harm to their communities, but also intervening in cases where families need help, aren't we undermining the principle of only intervening in situations where there's a clear threat to public safety or welfare, rather than using a more nuanced approach that considers the complexities of each individual case?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: What if the influx of immigrants receiving coverage under a potential Democratic presidential policy leads to a shift in the political landscape, potentially influencing the outcome of future elections and altering the interests of the Republican party, which could have unintended consequences for the party's stance on immigration and healthcare?

Do you have any evidence that immigration policies or xenophobic rhetoric by politicians actually prevent or reduce the likelihood of undocumented immigrants accessing healthcare, as opposed to just making them eligible for coverage through other means?

Wouldn't the logic of providing public services and benefits to undocumented immigrants, based on their integration into society, also imply a similar obligation to provide access to healthcare, given that it's a fundamental aspect of societal participation?
If xenophobic sentiments are so unwarranted in this case, why is the argument that illegal immigrants shouldn't receive coverage being compared to a Republican stance that was previously ridiculed?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: What if setting a maximum tarmac delay trigger for all airlines and all classes of aircraft leads to a significant increase in flight delays and cancellations due to the complexity of implementing and enforcing this policy, potentially causing more harm to passengers than the current system?
Can you provide evidence from CBP or airport security protocols that deplaning during gate holds without CBP screening poses no significant security risk?

If airlines are required to make a legal commitment (contract of carriage) to ensure the well-being of passengers in the event of tarmac delays, why can't they also be held accountable for the well-being of passengers in the event of prolonged CBP screening delays?

Why should the proposed tarmac delay trigger be limited to all airlines and all classes of aircraft, while the deplaning option is only suggested for passengers, potentially creating a disparate treatment among airline and passenger classes?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: What if airlines charging exorbitant fees for carrying pets as carry-on bags leads to a situation where many passengers are forced to check their pets, which could cause increased stress and anxiety for both humans and animals, potentially affecting air travel overall?

Do you have any data or research that demonstrates a direct causal link between airline seat size and configuration, and the development of deep vein thrombosis, to justify considering it a health issue?

If airlines are held responsible for providing a safe and healthy environment for passengers due to factors like seat size and configuration, why should they not also be held accountable for accommodating passengers with service animals, which can be essential for passengers' health and well-being?

If seat size and configuration are a health issue, then shouldn't airlines be required to provide a minimum standard of space for passengers rather than just offering exercises to mitigate the effects of their cramped seats?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: What if the implementation of a blanket ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights would not only protect passengers with severe allergies like the speaker's child but also inadvertently create a significant financial burden on the airline industry, potentially leading to increased ticket prices and reduced air travel options for the general public?

Don't you think that a blanket ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights could have unintended consequences, such as increased food waste, higher costs for airlines, and potential harm to people who are not allergic to these substances but rely on them for medical or therapeutic purposes?

If severe allergies that can cause anaphylaxis are grounds for banning substances on airplanes, why would a substance like carbon monoxide, which can also cause anaphylaxis, not also be subject to a similar ban?

If a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights is necessary to ensure the safety of individuals with severe allergies, why not also ban other items that pose a potential threat to passengers, such as sharp objects, open flames, or hazardous chemicals, to prevent a broader range of fatal accidents?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: What if the fact that a presidential candidate can rely solely on a website to communicate their policy and vision, rather than engaging in a traditional debate format, reflects a broader shift in the way people consume information and interact with politics?

Is there any empirical evidence that suggests politicians who communicate through unconventional means, such as responding with references to personal websites, are more effective in conveying their policy plans than those who adhere to traditional forms of communication?
If politicians can be held accountable for not providing a comprehensive plan, why should voters be expected to solely rely on their promises rather than tangible evidence and past records?

If the plan was indeed fully detailed on the website, why did the candidate feel the need to explicitly mention it was available, suggesting a lack of confidence in the audience's ability to find or understand it on their own?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: What if the airline industry's self-monitoring leads to inconsistent and inaccurate information, potentially causing anxiety or trauma in passengers, which could ultimately lead to physical or mental health issues that outweigh any potential economic benefits of unregulated customer service?

Does the airline industry's inability to self-regulate, as evidenced by variable, incomplete, or inaccurate information from customer service departments, truly outweigh the costs and logistical challenges associated with government oversight or industry-wide standards?

If the airline industry's self-regulation of customer service quality is likened to a person being left to self-monitor their own physical and mental health, would this not also lead to inconsistent, inaccurate, and potentially hazardous outcomes?

Doesn't the airline industry's inability to provide consistent and accurate information, coupled with the severe consequences of its lapses, justify government regulation and oversight to protect consumers, rather than relying solely on self-regulation?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: Do the opponents of accommodations, who claim to be driven by a concern for the potential risks associated with their implementation, not also have a responsibility to engage with the existing scientific research and evidence on the matter, rather than dismissing it outright due to their preconceived biases?

Don't you have any concern that your dismissal of opposing views and labeling of those who disagree as "meanspirited" undermines the spirit of constructive dialogue and compromise that you're advocating for?

Does the opponents' dismissal of the research and refusal to consider a compromise position, despite its credibility and international backing, not undermine the legitimacy of their claims that accommodations are unwarranted?

If opponents of accommodations are aware of credible research and yet refuse to engage with it, does their dismissal of the research constitute a form of intellectual tyranny, undermining the democratic values they claim to uphold?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: What if the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin is not the primary source of peanut allergens, but rather the peanuts themselves, and does that shift the responsibility of mitigating exposure to peanut allergens from the airline to the peanut consumers and the parents of peanut-allergic children?

Do you have any evidence from the study you're referring to that supports the claim that the recirculated air in an aircraft cabin is significantly cleaner than in most public buildings, and therefore, the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut allergens is minimal?

If airplane air is cleaner than in most public buildings, and desensitization to peanut allergies is a viable option, why are airlines and their passengers still expected to accommodate the fears of those with severe peanut allergies?

If peanut allergens can indeed be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners, and considering the low risk of anaphylactic shock from airborne peanut particles is already present outside an airline cabin, doesn't this study effectively demonstrate that airlines should take steps to minimize peanut allergen exposure in the cabin, rather than dismissing the concerns of peanut-allergic passengers as "petty fears"?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: What if the widespread prohibition of peanuts on airplanes actually leads to a black market for peanuts, causing more harm to those with genuine peanut allergies due to unregulated and potentially contaminated peanuts being sold to vulnerable individuals?

Do you have any credible evidence to support the claim that peanuts are "incredibly nutritious" and "quite filling in a small serving," considering the context of the ongoing debate about their impact on public health, particularly in relation to airline food policies?

If peanuts are indeed as nutritious and beneficial as howie claims, wouldn't the elimination of peanut distribution on airplanes be a counterintuitive decision, potentially depriving passengers of a valuable source of nutrition and comfort during flights?

Is it not a case of overreacting to a relatively low risk by eliminating peanuts on airplanes, when the more effective and less restrictive solution might be educating airline staff and passengers about proper food allergy management and emergency protocols?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: Don't airlines like the one you mentioned also have a potential cause-and-effect relationship where their pricing strategy could lead to customers like you feeling misled or deceived, thereby affecting their brand reputation and customer loyalty?

Do you have any evidence that the practice of varying prices in real-time or charging different prices to the same customer on the same day, as you claim is done by airlines, is indeed illegal under consumer protection laws, and that such practices would necessarily lead to the distrust and anger you described?

If airlines are guilty of deceptive pricing practices by advertising a low ticket price and then significantly increasing the cost with additional fees, why should retailers be exempt from similar scrutiny for their pricing strategies that may be perceived as "bait and switch" tactics?

If businesses like the airline can legally use deceptive pricing practices like bait and switch, why should consumers be expected to trust their pricing transparency and honesty in other retail settings?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldnâ€™t encourage it for ourselves either
Thatâ€™s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, thereâ€™s a danger I think when you kind of say, â€œThe poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.â€
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isnâ€™t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they havenâ€™t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: Doesn't the fact that the wealthy have historically been instrumental in driving social progress imply that their role is more complex than simply being the "bad guys," and shouldn't we be considering the potential consequences of villainizing them as a group?

Does your argument that well-off individuals can drive social progress and that banks should take more risks and give more money out not overlook the fact that excessive consumer credit and lack of responsible lending practices by banks have contributed to economic inequality and financial crises?

Doesn't the argument that the wealthy can drive social progress by making more productive investments overlook the systemic issues of power and privilege that allow them to accumulate wealth in the first place?

Isn't the assumption that wealthy individuals can be a driving force for social progress, as you've suggested, undermined by the fact that their primary motivations and actions often prioritize profit over people, especially in the case of banks that have been criticized for prioritizing consumer credit over more productive investments?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries â€“ and now the sufferers â€“ of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
â€œWell, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?â€
And you do actually want to say, â€œMoney doesnâ€™t grow on trees.â€"

cqs.cq: What if the political strategy of covering up the sub-prime mortgage issue inadvertently perpetuated a false sense of economic stability, leading to further financial recklessness among consumers?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that the current economic situation is a result of a deliberate policy rather than a series of unforeseen consequences of previous actions?

If the government's responsibility to rectify past injustices is acknowledged in the context of economic policy, why is the same responsibility not extended to addressing systemic inequalities and historical injustices in other areas, such as education, healthcare, or housing?
If you view this as a political strategy, doesn't that imply that the truth behind the situation is being deliberately obscured, rather than genuinely addressed?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that Trump's tax returns during the years he was under audit are not publicly available undermine Clinton's argument that he is hiding something in his tax returns, given the IRS's statement that releasing tax returns during an audit is not prohibited?

Does the claim that not releasing tax returns implies one is not as rich as claimed have any basis in fact, given that the only years of tax returns available for scrutiny are those from when Clinton was under state audit for a casino license?

Why does Clinton's argument that Trump's refusal to release his tax returns implies guilt, when applied to previous presidents who also did not release their tax returns, not hold her to the same standard of scrutiny?

Why would the lack of transparency in Trump's tax returns necessarily imply dishonesty about his wealth, charitable donations, or tax payments, when many factors could explain his decision not to release his returns?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: What if the systemic issues Clinton identifies, such as unequal education and biased policing, are not the primary causes of the problems she's describing, but rather symptoms of a deeper issue, and addressing them may not necessarily lead to the desired outcomes without also addressing the root causes?

Can you provide evidence that the issues of mistrust between communities and police, as well as police brutality, are more prevalent and widespread in the US than in other developed countries with similar socioeconomic conditions?

If racial disparities in the criminal justice system are acknowledged as a significant challenge, wouldn't the fact that police departments are predominantly composed of white officers, reflecting the racial demographics of the country, suggest a systemic issue that needs to be addressed in order to truly restore trust between communities and the police?

If restoring trust between communities and the police is a necessary step to address the issue of race, how can this be achieved without acknowledging and addressing the systemic issues that have led to the erosion of that trust in the first place?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: What if addressing the root causes of the gun epidemic, such as poverty, lack of education, and economic inequality, rather than solely focusing on gun control, would be a more effective way to reduce the leading cause of death of young African-American men?

Can you provide specific data or studies that support the claim that the "gun epidemic" is the leading cause of death of young African-American men, surpassing the next nine causes combined, considering the complexity of mortality rates and the need for a nuanced understanding of this issue?

Why does addressing the gun epidemic, which disproportionately affects young African-American men, not also involve addressing systemic issues such as economic inequality and lack of access to education, which may be underlying causes of this epidemic?

If we acknowledge that the gun epidemic is the leading cause of death among young African-American men, doesn't that imply that the current approach to addressing gun violence has been inadequate, and thus, does the proposed platform of merely restoring trust and working with the police sufficiently address the root causes of this issue?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe

We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on community policing and the supposed decrease in crime rates is actually masking a more complex issue, where systemic racism and socioeconomic disparities are driving the appearance of progress rather than actual change?
Can you provide evidence that community policing, as you describe it, has been proven to be more effective than other policing methods in reducing crime rates in predominantly black communities?

Does Clinton's emphasis on community policing and reducing crime inadvertently perpetuate the notion that black communities are inherently prone to crime, rather than addressing the systemic issues that contribute to higher crime rates?

If community policing has been shown to be effective in reducing violent and property crime, why do you believe that reinstating stop-and-frisk, a method that was deemed unconstitutional due to its ineffectiveness, would be a more effective solution in addressing public safety concerns?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
