cqs.cq: Don't you think that dismissing the concerns of a small but significant group like peanut allergy sufferers undermines the principles of inclusivity and accommodation that the founding of the U.S. is based on?

Can you provide a scientific study that specifically examines the impact of peanut allergy warnings on the rights of the majority versus the rights of peanut allergy sufferers, in order to justify your claim that the rights of the majority should be prioritized over those of a small minority?

If the founding of the U.S. is being used to justify the restriction of rights for a minority group, why can't similar historical justifications be used to restrict the rights of other minority groups?
If there's no real risk to peanut allergy sufferers, why are you advocating for restrictions that could potentially infringe upon the rights of the majority for a perceived threat that may not exist?

Mulder_226.input:
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."
 < this message is answering to > 
Samsmom: "I am utterly amazed at the ignorance displayed by some of those commenting here.
Allergies are not "perceived"
as Mulder suggests,
and it is ridiculous and unrealistic  to suggest that people with severe food allergies "live in a bubble".
No one who has an allergy chooses to be in this situation,
and walking onto an airplane where peanuts either are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette.
We are talking about a SNACK ON AN AIRPLANE.
Can you really be complaining about your rights to eat a snack?!?
My son could DIE because you can't forgo a snack for two hours.
While we could drive everywhere we need to go for the rest of his life,
there may come a time when time constraints force us to fly.
No matter how much "responsibility we take", we cannot sufficiently protect him if people around us are eating any peanut product.
We always carry an epipen,
and feel that should be our responsibility.
But, again, that may not be enough to save his life.
Those autoinjectors can only buy us 1015 minutes,
barely enough time for a plane to request an emergency landing site.
He would be dead before we taxied to the gate.
FOR A SNACK!!
An outright ban should be in place."

cqs.cq: What if the airline industry implemented stricter policies to minimize peanut exposure, such as peanut-free snack options or designated peanut-free zones, which could potentially mitigate the risks associated with peanut allergies without necessitating a complete ban on peanuts?

Does the likelihood of a fatal peanut allergy reaction on an airplane, which is estimated to be extremely low, justify the imposition of a blanket ban on serving peanuts on flights when there are alternative measures available, such as strict cleaning protocols and allergy-friendly seating, to minimize the risk?

If airline passengers with severe food allergies are required to take responsibility for their own safety and forgo certain snacks, wouldn't the same expectation be placed on the airline industry to take responsibility for accommodating passengers with severe allergies, rather than forcing them to take drastic measures?

If eliminating the risk of peanut allergy reactions is so crucial, why should airlines be allowed to continue serving peanuts as an optional snack when the risk of anaphylaxis could be eliminated by removing peanuts from the menu altogether?

Mulder_240.input:
Mulder: "You're the one who seems to be partisan.
Instead of thinking logically about it, you try to deflect blame for your misguided apprehension onto others by insinuating they have a compulsion.
Serving and eating peanuts is not a public health menace,
so you need to get over it.
Instead of conflating the possible with the inevitable, you should focus on the reality, which is that the possibility is extremely small.
You're more likely to die from getting hit by a car crossing the street, yet you're not advocating we ban driving.
That's being a hypocrite."
 < this message is answering to > 
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."

cqs.cq: What if Mulder's argument that peanut consumption on airplanes is extremely rare and not a public health menace is based on flawed assumptions and lack of concrete data, leading him to downplay the actual risks associated with peanut allergies and anaphylaxis?

Do you have any data or studies that support the claim that peanut consumption on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace comparable to tobacco smoking, considering the actual risks and statistics surrounding food allergies and anaphylaxis?

Is it not inconsistent for you to compare the hypothetical addictive behavior of peanut consumers to actual addictive disorders while simultaneously advocating for a blanket restriction on a food item, rather than addressing the underlying issues of addiction through education and support?

If the peanut consumption issue is indeed as crucial as you claim, shouldn't the same level of urgency and drastic measures be applied to address the more pressing issue of peanuts being a common ingredient in many other food products and not just served on airplanes?

ND_28.input:
ND: "In some ways I agree with you
If you want the economy to run smoothly, you have to incentivise certain types of behaviour.
So, for example in South Korea, in terms of how South Korean grew, it did incentivise saving, at certain times, by certain economic policies
On the other hand, I think what people donâ€™t realise, or only half realise, is the fact that we have actually written off massive amounts of debt
But it certainly isnâ€™t the debts of the people who most need it in society
For productive investments. I agree with you."

cqs.cq: What if the economic policies that incentivise certain types of behaviour, such as saving, ultimately lead to a society where those who are already financially secure accumulate more wealth and power, while those who are already disadvantaged are left further behind?

Don't you think that incentivizing certain types of behaviour in the economy could potentially lead to unintended consequences, such as exacerbating income inequality, if those who already have the means to save are disproportionately rewarded?

If economic policies can incentivize certain behaviors by offering benefits to specific groups, why would the same logic not be applied to address systemic inequalities, such as student loan forgiveness or reparations, to incentivize productive behaviors among marginalized communities?

If incentivising certain types of behaviour is crucial for a smooth economy, doesn't that imply that those who have been left with the burden of written-off debts, particularly those who need it most, are being unfairly incentivised to be financially strained?

NYCMuscleman18_161.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: If charging passengers based on weight is indeed discriminatory, then why does the airline industry not face widespread public backlash and regulatory action for what appears to be a clear case of unfair treatment?

Do you have any data or studies that support the claim that the cost of checked baggage is directly correlated with the weight of the passenger, and not just based on other factors such as airline pricing policies or fuel costs?

If the airline industry can discriminate against individuals based on their weight for the purpose of pricing, why can't other businesses discriminate against individuals based on their physical characteristics, such as height or age, for similar purposes?

Is it not discriminatory for the airline industry to charge passengers based on weight, potentially pricing out or disproportionately burdening individuals who are larger, similar to how we would not tolerate discriminatory practices based on other characteristics like race or gender?

NYCMuscleman18_187.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "Agreed.
The most frustrating thing about airline travel is the lack of space.
I don't see why they care so much about letting people game the bumping system, but not at all about personal space.
I guess the big question is, what's DOT's job, exactly?
Is this about inair convenience?
Avoiding pricegouging?
Or something else?"
 < this message is answering to > 
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: If airlines are indeed responsible for addressing seat size and configuration as a health issue to prevent deep vein thrombosis, then why do they not prioritize the provision of adequate legroom and seat space as a standard feature rather than relying on passengers to pay extra for it?

Can you provide any evidence from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) or the Department of Transportation (DOT) that specifically addresses the issue of airline seat size and configuration as a health concern, rather than a matter of passenger comfort?

If airlines are held responsible for providing a safe and healthy environment for passengers, shouldn't they also be accountable for providing a safe and respectful environment for service animals, just as they are for carry-on pets?

If seat size and configuration are considered a health issue, shouldn't airlines be held accountable for the health risks associated with their cramped seating, rather than simply requiring passengers to perform exercises to mitigate those risks?

PeanutAllergy_232.input:
PeanutAllergy: "My son is allergic to peanuts.
The last time we flew on an airline that served peanuts (Southwest) we called ahead and requested that no peanuts be served on our flight.
The airline was extremely accommodating, but there were peanuts on the floor and between the seats from earlier flights.
For that reason, I don't see banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanutfree buffer zone as real solutions.
We now only fly airlines that don't serve peanuts.
We're okay with Snickers because the peanuts are less likely to get spilled.
However, this wouldn't be a good solution for those with an inhalation allergy.
Maybe the ban could extend to all foods when there is a specific request."

cqs.cq: If a peanut allergy is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition, would requiring airlines to implement a comprehensive peanut-free policy on all flights, rather than relying on individual requests and the likelihood of spills, be a more effective solution to ensure passenger safety?

Does your personal experience of peanuts being present on flights after they were requested not to be served constitute sufficient evidence to justify a blanket policy of banning peanuts on all flights, when there are likely to be more severe peanut allergies that could be better addressed through other means?

If airlines can be held responsible for accommodating passengers with peanut allergies, why shouldn't they also be responsible for accommodating passengers with food sensitivities or allergies that are not as severe, such as lactose intolerance or gluten intolerance?

If accommodating passengers with peanut allergies requires airlines to limit or eliminate peanuts on specific flights, doesn't that set a precedent for other passengers with severe allergies to expect similar accommodations for their respective allergens?

PracticalJo_179_1.input:
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack."

cqs.cq: What if the removal of peanuts from planes would lead to airlines replacing them with other high-risk food items, potentially exacerbating the allergy problem and causing more severe reactions among passengers?

Don't airlines already have policies in place to prevent peanut-related incidents, such as not allowing peanuts on planes or providing peanut-free alternatives, which could potentially mitigate the risks you mentioned, making the call for a blanket ban unnecessary?

If removing peanuts and peanut products from planes is primarily motivated by concerns over severe reactions and safety, why not also consider removing other potentially hazardous food items like shellfish or tree nuts, which pose similar ingestion risks?

Why should the removal of peanuts from planes be prioritized over other potential allergens or irritants that could be present on flights, when the solution proposed by the airlines already seems to be effective in mitigating the risks associated with peanuts?

PracticalJo_179_2.input:
PracticalJo: "Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: What if the failure to provide EpiPens or other medications for passengers with severe allergies, despite the potential for severe reactions from peanut residue on aircraft, leads to a situation where a passenger's allergy causes a fatal anaphylactic shock, resulting in a lawsuit against the airline that could lead to significant financial losses and reputational damage?
Do you have any data or studies that demonstrate a significant correlation between the current airline cleaning protocols and the reduction of peanut allergy incidents on commercial flights?

If airlines are required to accommodate passengers with severe allergies by providing EpiPens or other medications, should they not also be required to take similar precautions to prevent peanut exposure for passengers with peanut allergies?
If airlines are already required to provide EpiPens for passengers with severe allergies, why should they be exempt from taking additional measures to minimize peanut exposure on their aircraft?

Qubbin_80.input:
Qubbin: "I generally support the idea,
but it should be limited only to those fees which are variable,
They should not be allowed to list fees separately that are part of a ticket fee for every ticket issued,
This process serves no purpose other than to show a lower base fee.
That is misleading and meaningless.
If they want to show these components of a ticket, so be it,
but not to suggest a price which could never be exercised."

cqs.cq: What if allowing airlines to list fees separately from the base ticket price actually leads to consumers being misled about the true cost of the ticket, causing them to make decisions based on incorrect information?

Can you provide empirical evidence that limiting the listing of separate fees on tickets, as you suggest, would actually prevent companies from engaging in deceptive pricing practices, rather than simply making the prices more transparent?
If ticket issuers are allowed to break down fixed fees into variable components, wouldn't this create a misleading and arbitrary pricing system that could be exploited for financial gain?

If listing fees separately serves no purpose other than to show a lower base fee, then why does it matter if the overall fee appears higher to consumers, potentially discouraging them from purchasing tickets?

SWong_118_1.input:
SWong: "My son is severely allergic to peanuts and has allergic reactions as a result of being around people eating peanuts due to the peanut dust in the air.
We had to travel internationally and were able to work with the airline to book peanut free roundtrip flights after submitting a letter from my son's allergist.
The airline did everything they could including serving snacks without peanuts, putting allergy alert stickers on our seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating their peanut snacks.
My son was fine going to our destination but had an allergic reaction within minutes of being seated for our return trip.
Since he didn't eat any peanuts, we gave him some benadryl, moved him to a different row, and wiped down his new seat.
We were fortunate that his reaction was not severe enough to require an epipen injection and a trip to the hospital in another country."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's extensive accommodations and precautions taken in response to my son's allergy were insufficient, leading to a severe allergic reaction, would that have been a direct result of the airline's negligence in prioritizing the needs of passengers with severe allergies?

Do you have any data or studies that show the airline's efforts to accommodate your son's peanut allergy were sufficient to prevent the reaction, or was the airline's implementation of the accommodations inadequate, despite their best efforts?

If the airline took extensive precautions to accommodate a passenger with a peanut allergy, why should a person of color not be able to expect similar accommodations for a condition that is not a choice, but rather a result of systemic injustices?

If the airline took such extensive precautions to accommodate your son's peanut allergy on the way to your destination, why did they fail to take similar precautions on the return trip, despite having prior knowledge of your son's condition and the airline's experience with peanut allergy accommodations?

SWong_118_2.input:
SWong: "We suspect that he was reacting to peanut residue in the area of his seat from the previous flight.
We may not be so lucky next time because we have been told that the next reaction is even stronger than the last.
Even though we were on a peanutfree fight, my son still was not safe because of the peanut residue on the plane from a previous flight.
If peanuts are banned on all flights, my son would have been safe.
When an allergic reaction occurs high up in the sky over a huge ocean, and an epipen injection can only give a person an extra 20 minutes, there is not enough time to turn the plane around and take the person to the hospital.
I believe that it is reasonable to ban peanuts from airline flights if that assures the safety of a passenger that has a severe peanut allergy.
This decision could mean life or death for someone."

cqs.cq: What if banning peanuts from flights would not guarantee the complete elimination of peanut residue on planes, as there could still be contamination from other sources, such as passengers who consume peanuts on the ground before boarding, or from peanuts that have been stored on the plane?

Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that peanuts are more likely to be present in sufficient quantities on a plane to cause a severe allergic reaction, considering the thorough cleaning procedures typically followed by airlines after each flight?

Would it not be equally reasonable to ban other common allergenic foods, such as tree nuts, shellfish, or soy, given that peanut allergy is not the only life-threatening condition that can be triggered by in-flight allergen exposure?

Isn't it true that banning peanuts from all flights would be a blanket policy that fails to account for passengers who are not allergic to peanuts, potentially causing more harm by creating a false sense of security and unnecessary restrictions on passengers who do not have a peanut allergy?

Sithsaber__198.input:
Sithsaber: "Have you been to high school
It's shit"
 < this message is answering to > 
g: "high school is high school, college is college"

cqs.cq: What if the tone and language used in this exchange reflect a broader societal issue where the devaluation of high school education contributes to a lack of motivation and respect for students who pursue it?

Are you suggesting that your experience of high school is representative of the universal experience, or are you simply dismissing the differences between high school and college based on your own biases?
Does labeling a high school experience as "high school" while considering a college experience as distinct imply that the value and significance of these educational milestones differ in some way?

Is it not ironic that you, who seem to be belittling the value of education by referring to it as "shit", are now trying to differentiate between high school and college as if the former is somehow inferior?

SofieM_128.input:
SofieM: "Keep in mind that you wouldn't be able to get out of the plane if it were in the air, either.
I think deplaning is a bit extreme,
because it could throw an already imbalanced flight schedule out of whack, and might delay flights even further or lead to cancellation.
I sat on a tarmac in London for five hours earlier this year, but I'd rather wait it out than hop off the plane and miss an opportunity to take off.
However, I see no problem with regular passenger updates on the progress of the delay."

cqs.cq: What if passengers who are deplaning due to a significant delay end up being more likely to miss their connections or other flights, causing a ripple effect that ultimately delays the overall flight schedule more than if they had simply waited on the plane?

Do you have any data or studies that demonstrate the extent to which passengers who deplane during delays experience a significant increase in stress or anxiety compared to those who wait on the plane, which could inform a more nuanced approach to handling flight delays?
If delaying flights for an extended period is deemed acceptable, would not allowing passengers to deplane also be seen as a necessary measure to prevent further disruptions to the flight schedule?

If deplaning is seen as an extreme measure that could lead to cancellations or further delays, then why would you expect airlines to handle a delay of several hours on the tarmac without providing regular updates to passengers?

SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,
so I wouldn't be so quick to discount the incentive that customer satisfaction plays to airlines.
Here is an excerpt from the proposed rule:
"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).
Any business which intends to survive has to satisfy its customers, otherwise the customers will simply stop buying their product, and the business will go bankrupt. Airlines themselves already thought up flight status notifications because there was customer demand for them.
I find it interesting that you claim neither passengers nor profits to be benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs.
Now, air fare is affordable (prices of air fares have decreased 25% since 1991) and more available to citizens than ever before.
Airlines like Southwest are benefiting exactly because they are offering low fares, serving their customer needs, which would seem to disprove your statement that both profits and passengers suffer in the status quo."

cqs.cq: If the airlines themselves have already recognized the importance of providing timely and accurate flight information to customers, and are offering low fares that cater to customer needs, why is it necessary for the DOT to impose regulations on the provision of flight notifications?

Do you have any data that suggests the airlines' current flight notification systems are not primarily driven by customer satisfaction, but rather by other factors such as regulatory compliance or cost reduction, rather than genuine customer demand?

Does the airline industry's adoption of customer-driven flight notifications suggest that the current state of air transit affairs, despite perceived drawbacks, inherently serves the best interests of both passengers and airlines, contradicting the notion that significant reforms are necessary?

Don't airline companies that offer timely and accurate flight information, like Southwest, contradict the DOT's argument that it's the government's responsibility to provide flight notifications, thus implying that airlines can effectively manage this issue on their own?

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: What if the assumption that parents know their children better than the airlines does not always hold true, and wouldn't a more nuanced approach to airline policies account for the varying abilities and readiness of children to travel alone?

Can you provide empirical evidence that supports the claim that parents are more equipped to make informed decisions about their children's abilities to handle travel than the airlines, which have experience in assessing the capabilities of thousands of minors?

Wouldn't blanket policies regarding travel restrictions for minors inadvertently mirror discriminatory practices by applying a one-size-fits-all solution to an issue that requires nuanced consideration of individual circumstances?
Don't blanket policies on airline travel restrictions for minors undermine the ability of parents to make informed decisions about their children's readiness for independent travel?

TRUMP_101.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not negotiable , no
Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"

cqs.cq: What if the release of Hillary Clinton's deleted emails could potentially reveal information that would cause a significant shift in public opinion, thereby affecting the outcome of the election?

Do you have any evidence from a credible source that supports the claim that deleting 33,000 emails is an indicator of wrongdoing or a relevant issue in the context of the conversation about Hillary Clinton?

If the scrutiny of Hillary Clinton's deleted emails is considered a matter of public interest and national security, wouldn't the potential security risks and implications of Donald Trump's handling of classified information also warrant a similar level of transparency and investigation?
Why does the president imply that Hillary Clinton's deletion of 33,000 e-mails is a matter of public concern, but the deletion of potentially thousands of records by the Trump administration is not?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: If peanuts and other tree nuts can become airborne and cause a severe allergic reaction even if not ingested, then shouldn't planes have a stricter policy in place to prevent passengers from bringing these items on board altogether, rather than just designating certain areas as "nut-free" or relying on passengers to self-regulate?

Do you have any scientific evidence that suggests the airborne dust from tree nuts and peanuts poses a significant enough risk to justify a blanket ban on their presence on planes, considering the potential inconvenience and economic burden it may impose on airlines and passengers who do not have nut allergies?

If airlines are required to accommodate passengers with severe nut allergies by banning nuts on planes, why are they not also obligated to provide accommodations for passengers with severe reactions to other airborne allergens, such as dust or chemicals?

If a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes is deemed necessary to ensure the safety of those with severe nut allergies, why can't airlines implement stricter measures to enforce this ban, such as thorough pre-flight screenings or increased penalties for passengers who bring prohibited items onto the plane?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: If airlines claim that banning nuts on flights is necessary for passenger safety, yet they still allow passengers to bring on nuts and refrain from intervening when others eat them, wouldn't this create a contradictory policy that undermines the supposed safety concerns?

Is there any scientific evidence that supports the claim that allowing passengers to bring on and eat nuts poses a significant health risk to others on a flight, given the fact that airlines already allow other potentially allergenic foods and do not intervene when passengers consume them?

If airlines can accommodate the needs of passengers with nut allergies by implementing a 'nut-free' flight policy, why can't they also accommodate the needs of passengers with peanut sensitivities or preferences by banning peanuts from being brought on board?
If airlines can't or won't prevent passengers from eating nuts on flights, why should they be expected to implement a blanket "nut-free" policy when passengers with severe allergies are present?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: What if the proposed auction system, which could provide a more tailored and fair compensation for bumped passengers, is implemented, would it not mitigate the issue of the current compensation limits being too low and arbitrarily unfair, thereby reducing the need for mandatory cash payment options?

Does the proposed auction method suggested by Julian Simon not create a scenario where carriers could exploit passengers by offering unrealistically low starting bids, thereby undermining the incentive to limit overbooking?

If mandatory compensation for bumped passengers who lack check cashing privileges at their destination is deemed necessary, why wouldn't a similar consideration be given to passengers who lack access to secure credit or electronic payment methods?

Why would the implementation of a mandatory cash payment option and an auction system for bumped passengers necessarily reduce the frequency of overbooking, when it may simply incentivize airlines to strategically overbook to capture the potential revenue from the auction system?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: Wouldn't an auction-based system for handling overbooked flights potentially lead to passengers bidding against each other, potentially exacerbating the problem of those who are unable to afford the highest bids being involuntarily denied boarding?

Don't you think that relying solely on auctions to price delays and compensate passengers may not account for the emotional and psychological factors involved in involuntary denials of boarding, such as stress, anxiety, and long-term reputational damage to the airline?

If the airlines' goal of overbooking is to optimize their financial results, would not a similar logic be applied to other business practices that involve over-allocating resources, such as hotel rooms or hospital beds, and would that not lead to a more efficient and customer-friendly approach?

Wouldn't the implementation of an auction system on overbooked flights primarily benefit airlines by increasing revenue, potentially exacerbating the problem of overbooking and involuntary denials of boarding, rather than addressing the root issue of airlines taking responsibility for their own scheduling decisions?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: What if forcing airlines to fully reimburse passengers for flight schedule changes could lead to increased flight cancellations due to over-bookings, potentially resulting in decreased flight options and higher ticket prices for all passengers?

Don't you think that requiring airlines to fully reimburse passengers for schedule changes could lead to abuse by passengers who might book flights at the last minute, expecting to cancel and rebook at a lower price, thereby undermining the airline's ability to manage their schedules effectively?

Wouldn't the airlines' frequent changes to flight schedules, which often result in significant inconveniences to passengers, be analogous to the argument that whites who benefit from stolen land after two generations should also be held accountable, implying that the airlines should also be required to compensate passengers similarly to how the US compensates indigenous peoples?

If airlines are allowed to change flight schedules frequently without compensation or consideration for passengers' plans, wouldn't this undermine the incentive for passengers like you to book flights well in advance, thereby potentially leading to increased ticket prices and reduced availability for those who need to plan ahead?

elizwestley_222.input:
elizwestley: "A peanutfree table is less likely to have smears of peanut butter on/under it.
Risk of exposure is reduced
which is not as good as eliminated but is better than full exposure.
I see the parallel with these flight proposals.
Ban peanut products.
Yes, people will "sneak" them.
However, the risk will still be reduced over the nothing that we are doing now."

cqs.cq: What if the proposed ban on peanut products leads to a black market or increased smuggling of peanuts, thereby undermining the intended reduction in risk and potentially creating new problems?

Do you have any scientific studies or data that demonstrate the efficacy of reducing the risk of peanut exposure through banning peanut products, rather than implementing more targeted and effective measures to minimize exposure in schools and public spaces?

Does the argument that banning peanut products is analogous to the original statement about races and stolen land, implying that a partial solution (reduced exposure) is preferable to no solution at all, similarly suggest that prohibiting certain foods could be an effective way to address health issues or allergies, even if it might not eliminate them entirely?

If eliminating peanut products is considered effective in reducing the risk of exposure to peanut allergies, doesn't banning them entirely potentially create a false sense of security, rather than eliminating the risk altogether?

elizwestley_68.input:
elizwestley: "I've registered my son on a flight as peanutallergic and had the attendant try to hand him a bag of peanuts.
Flight personnel need more education on this."

cqs.cq: What if flight personnel were trained to handle peanut allergy situations more effectively, would that reduce the likelihood of accidental exposure to peanuts for passengers with allergies?
Do you have any data or studies that demonstrate a direct correlation between flight attendants' educational background and their ability to properly handle peanut allergies on flights?

If airlines require passengers to be informed about and accommodate severe food allergies, why would they not also be responsible for ensuring that flight attendants understand the severity of life-threatening conditions like peanut allergies, potentially saving a child's life?

If airlines can be held accountable for accommodating passengers with severe peanut allergies, shouldn't they also be responsible for ensuring the safety of passengers with other life-threatening conditions, such as severe food allergies or anaphylaxis?

golff4fun_155.input:
golff4fun: "I think it's important to stress the real reason that aircraft is not returning to the gate.
Once the aircraft pulls away from the jetway, the crew is on the clock.
They are not being paid while sitting at a gate.
And 3 hours is too long to keep people on a grounded airplane."
 < this message is answering to > 
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' primary concern is not the passengers' well-being but rather the potential liability and financial implications of prolonged gate holds, which could lead to significant operational and reputational costs?

Don't you think that deplaning during gate holds could actually increase the risk of security breaches, as it would require passengers to be in the immediate area without proper screening, potentially undermining the very security measures you're advocating for?

If the concept of allowing passengers to deplane during gate holds is comparable to an open-ended delay prior to boarding, shouldn't airlines also be held accountable for the well-being of passengers during prolonged tarmac delays, including providing compensation for the time they spend waiting on the aircraft?

If aircraft crews are not being paid while sitting at a gate, then doesn't that imply that the airline is already accounting for the time spent waiting to depart in their operational costs, making the 3-hour maximum tarmac delay trigger less necessary?

golff4fun_162.input:
golff4fun: "Since weight seems to be the issue with charging extra fees for checked luggage,
the 98 lb person should pay less for a ticket than the 250 pounder.
I have thought that from the very beginning when the airlines introduced this new fee."
 < this message is answering to > 
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.

cqs.cq: What if the airline's decision to charge extra fees based on weight disproportionately affects individuals with medical conditions that cause weight fluctuations, potentially leading to financial hardship and unequal treatment for those who cannot control their weight?

Don't you think that applying a weight-based fee for checked luggage could unfairly penalize individuals who have a higher muscle mass or bone density, rather than just excess weight, potentially violating the Americans with Disabilities Act?

If weight-based pricing for checked luggage is deemed discriminatory, why wouldn't a similar argument be made for charging passengers based on their body mass index (BMI), as it's also a measure of weight in relation to height?

Wouldn't the argument that the airline should not charge more for the 250-pounder's checked luggage due to weight also imply that airlines should provide larger seats or more legroom for heavier passengers, rather than just offering a discounted rate?

grayk47__302.input:
grayk47: " you give an illegally (as in you stole it) acquired firearm to a friend to use responsibly
that person accidentally shoots someone
who should be blamed
Both should be held responsible

It's cut and dry"

cqs.cq: If the person who received the illegally acquired firearm was not given the proper training or guidance on its safe handling and use, do you think they would still be considered responsible for the accidental shooting?

Do you have any scientific source or legal precedent that supports the notion that the distinction between 'illegally acquired' and 'illegally distributed' information is irrelevant in determining culpability for the consequences of that information?

hgranato_211.input:
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: What if a blanket ban on peanuts on flights were to lead to a scenario where airlines are unable to accommodate passengers with severe tree nut allergies, potentially putting them at risk of anaphylaxis?

Don't you think that requiring airlines to have precautions in place and ensuring that passengers with severe allergies are equipped to take proactive steps to manage their condition is a more feasible and effective solution than implementing a blanket ban on peanuts, considering the significant logistical challenges and potential economic impact on the airline industry?

Why would the same principle of personal responsibility and proactive steps not be applied to other individuals with severe food allergies, rather than relying solely on airlines to provide accommodations?

If we prioritize accommodating individuals with severe food allergies over the potential risks of a few, wouldn't such a ban also imply that we should accommodate and provide special arrangements for those with other severe allergies, such as gluten or shellfish, and potentially create an unsustainable and impractical system of catering to every individual's needs?

howie_201.input:
howie: "First, stop reading that propaganda magazine.
Publications like that only serve to create fear in minds like yours.
Second, how old is your kid?
If under 5, relax the sensitivity will probably go away by the time he is 5.
Third, go to a real doctor  not an allergist and see if there is really even a problem at all.
This supposed plague of food allergies is the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists.
Allergists are not doctors.
I sincerely doubt you "know plenty of people who will die if they do have peanuts or breathe in peanut dust".
Almost noone is actually that allergic.
Lot's of people think they are much worse off than they really are.
Methinks you have an agenda.
Highly suspicious that the child of a physician who is hyper aware of bad things that can happen coincidentally has not one, but three life threatening allergies.
Have you heard of Munchasen by Proxy?
Do you realize that most kids have mild reactions to various food items that they invariably grow out of by the age of 5?
Food allergies have to be the most overblown imagined health problem of our time.
Hypochondriacs all."
 < this message is answering to > 
jsooudi: "I'm a physician, epidemiologist, and mother to a four year old boy with allergies to milk, peanuts and egg.
My son's dairy allergy is severe,
and he has had numerous lifethreatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk,
which required multiple doses of epinephrine and trips to the Emergency Department.
Tests indicate that his peanut allergy is worse,
but fortunately he has only been exposed once to a peanut;
he put one in his mouth and had a relatively mild  reaction.
I've traveled with my children
and despite calling ahead, making requests, and reminding employees at the door, I've rarely had respect, let alone consistency, in any kind of peanutfree buffer zone or flight.
Several years ago Continental Airlines customer service headquarters informed me that they would serve peanuts on all flights as they were unable to guarantee a peanut free flight.
(So why not hand out weapons since they can't guarantee a weapon free flight either?)
I've sat with my epi pen in hand on a filthy flight with visible peanut crumbs on the floor while a flight attendant insisted on offering peanuts to the passengers around me because "it was their right."
Fortunately for me, my son's peanut allergy is not severe enough that it prohibits us from air travel.
Now that he is old enough to not put things in his mouth, and to protect himself, we are safer.
However, I know of many, many others in the allergy community, children and adults who simply can NOT fly.
My son's dairy allergy is quite severe.
The world would be a much safer place for us if no one consumed milk near him.
If his skin touches anything that once touched milk, even if it was partially cleaned, he will get severe hives.
If he consumes even less than a drop, within seconds his lips, eyes and face will swell, he will be covered in hives, vomit, and be gasping for breath.
Without epinephrine he would probably die within minutes.
But milk is ubiquitous,
and milk allergy relatively uncommon,
so we must protect ourselves.
Peanut allergy is common,
and it is a simple step to serve an alternative peanut based snacks for a short period of time.
So why is this a big problem?
The vast majority of potential reactions would be eliminated by simply avoiding snacks that have peanuts or peanut butter as an ingredient.
Peanut oil is known to contain very little of the actual peanut protein,
and would be of little risk in an airborne environment.
As a physician, I have responded to the call from airline staff asking for emergency medical assistance.
I am well aware of how expensive and inconvenient it is to ground a plane.
In addition, most epipens come in two pack doses,
each of which are good for maybe 10 to 15 minutes.
Which in a severe anaphylactic reaction is simply not enough time between the beginning of a reaction and the patient reaching EMS.
I've found that other passengers, as a rule, are extremely supportive,
and are more than happy to help with a fellow passengers safety.
I think the people commenting on this site would react entirely differently were they seated next to an allergic child on a plane.
Of course they would refrain from eating peanuts for a few hours if they knew it would hurt someone they were looking in the face.
But I am sympathetic to individuals who are unhappy with yet another discomfort inflicted on air travelers.
This restriction is designed to protect people with allergies from the airlines callous disregard for cleanliness and for our safety, not from our fellow passengers.
"Hi.  My name is Steven.  I am 4 years old.
I am allergic to peanuts, eggs and cow milk.
If I eat a peanut I'll get sick.
I ate a nut one time and got a big bump on my lip and it swelled up and it was hard to breathe.
It was scary and my dad gave me some medicine that made it better.
I would like for them to not give out peanuts so I won't get sick because I'm allergic.
Everybody should drink Sprite and eat Pringles and Pretzels.""

cqs.cq: What if the airline industry's refusal to implement a peanut-free flight policy leads to a severe anaphylactic reaction on a flight, resulting in the death of a child with a peanut allergy, and what would be the consequences of such an event on the airline's liability and the public's perception of their safety standards?

Can you provide any evidence from a reputable medical organization, such as the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology, that supports the claim that the majority of children grow out of their food allergies by the age of 5?

Wouldn't your expectation that airlines should provide a peanut-free environment for passengers with severe allergies, and your experience as a mother of a child with life-threatening allergies, be similar to the expectation that people of color have of being treated equally and without discrimination, given the historical and ongoing struggles of systemic racism in society?

If you're so concerned about your son's allergies, why don't you also advocate for stricter regulations on the dairy industry to prevent your son from being exposed to milk in the first place, given that his dairy allergy is equally severe and potentially life-threatening?

howie_208.input:
howie: "Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from eating peanuts?
Didn't think so.
Most food allergies are imagined.
You clearly have a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy.
If someone is actually that allergic, they should stay home and not inconvenience the rest of us."
 < this message is answering to > 
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.

cqs.cq: What if accommodating the needs of individuals with severe peanut allergies, such as restricting or banning peanut products on airlines, inadvertently leads to a false sense of security among passengers without severe allergies, potentially causing them to become complacent and less vigilant about their own allergy risks, and ultimately increasing the risk of accidental exposure and reactions among those who are not as severely affected?

Does your proposed ban on peanuts on airlines, despite the availability of alternative food options, not unfairly penalize passengers who are not severely allergic and disproportionately inconvenience them, particularly in situations where peanuts are a necessary component of the meal service?

Can a blanket ban on peanuts on all airlines, which would undoubtedly cause significant inconvenience and economic burden, truly be justified when the risk of severe reactions from airborne peanut residue or cross-contamination is relatively low, especially considering the availability of effective safety measures and the efforts of medical professionals like yourself to mitigate such risks?

Your ailment is not shared by the general population,
and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."

given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' efforts to accommodate passengers with severe food allergies could inadvertently create a new set of risks or liabilities that outweigh the benefits of such accommodations?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: What if the widespread misconception of food allergies, including peanut allergies, is caused by a combination of misinformation and societal anxiety, which in turn leads to unnecessary restrictions on a nutritious food source?
Does the absence of reported peanut-related deaths on planes, as mentioned by the speaker, necessarily imply that peanut allergies are entirely imagined or overhyped?

Does the risk of an extremely rare severe peanut allergy justify the drastic measures of banning peanuts on planes, or would a more measured approach, such as accommodating passengers with severe allergies, be a more reasonable solution?
Isn't it contradictory to dismiss the risks associated with peanuts for the majority of people while disregarding the legitimate concerns of those with severe, medically diagnosed allergies?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: If peanut-free flights are effective in preventing life-threatening reactions, why haven't all airlines followed Northwest's example and prohibited peanuts altogether, considering the potential consequences of inaction?

Can you provide any scientific evidence that supports the claim that the circulation of peanut dust in the air is a significant risk factor for anaphylaxis, as opposed to the presence of peanuts themselves?

Would the airline's refusal to prohibit peanuts on flights be comparable to the historical refusal of society to acknowledge the harm caused by smoking, given the airline's knowledge of the guaranteed life-threatening reactions it can cause for individuals like the author?

If airlines can accommodate smokers by creating nonsmoking zones and eventually prohibit smoking altogether, why can't they take similar steps to minimize peanut exposure for passengers like you, considering the severity of peanut allergies?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: If peanuts pose such a significant risk to passengers with life-threatening allergies, do airlines have a moral obligation to prioritize their safety and take more drastic measures to eliminate peanuts from flights altogether, rather than simply offering peanut-free flights as an option?

Can you provide evidence from the scientific community that supports the claim that peanuts pose a unique risk to individuals with peanut allergies, as opposed to other allergenic foods, that justifies the complete ban of nut products on planes?

If a peanut allergy poses a unique risk to passengers due to the potential for airborne particles and sticky substances, why not also consider banning or providing alternatives for passengers with other potentially deadly allergies, such as shellfish or soy, which could pose similar risks in different contexts?

If peanut-free flights are so crucial for protecting people with severe allergies, why not also offer nut-free hotel rooms, restaurants, and other public spaces, given the potential for anaphylactic reactions to occur anywhere?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: What if prioritizing comfort and ergonomics in airline seating leads to increased passenger satisfaction, reduced fatigue, and subsequently higher ticket prices, which could make air travel even more unaffordable for the average consumer?

Do you have any data or studies that support the claim that the primary issue with economy class seating is specifically the lack of space, rather than other factors such as in-flight entertainment, meal options, or overall comfort amenities?

If airlines prioritize ergonomic design and comfort for their economy class seats, would that not set a precedent for reevaluating the overall flying experience, potentially shifting air travel from a necessary evil to a more enjoyable experience?

If airlines prioritize improving ergonomics and comfort in economy class seats, wouldn't that ultimately lead to increased customer satisfaction and loyalty, potentially offsetting the costs associated with implementing such changes?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: Would allowing pets to travel in the cabin with their owners, secured by a seatbelt, potentially lead to a decrease in pet travel revenue for airlines, as pet owners might opt to travel more frequently if they can bring their pets along, thus offsetting any potential benefits to the airlines from increased ticket sales?

Do you have any data or studies that demonstrate the correlation between allowing pets to travel in the cabin with their owners and increased customer satisfaction and retention, considering the potential costs and stress associated with the current cargo system?

If airlines are allowed to prioritize the comfort and safety of some human passengers over others, why should a pet owner not be allowed to prioritize the comfort and well-being of their pet, who is also a paying customer in their own right?

If prioritizing customer satisfaction and pet owners' convenience can justify accommodating larger dogs in the cabin, why can't airlines also accommodate passengers with disabilities or those who require special medical equipment, which may be just as bulky or stressful to handle in cargo?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate

some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting

no one had ever heard of him

 he's a competitive candidate

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!

and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
